'''''Amanita smithiana''''', also known as '''Smith's amanita''', is a species of [[agaric]] found on soil in [[conifer]]ous (''[[Abies]]'', ''[[Tsuga]]'', ''[[Pseudotsuga]]'') and broadleaved (''[[Alder|Alnus]]'', ''[[Quercus]]'') woodland in the [[Pacific Northwest]] of North America. It fruits in August and September.

==Taxonomy==
''Amanita smithiana'' was [[species description|described]] by Dutch mycologist [[Cornelis Bas]] in 1969. The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] honors mycologist [[Alexander H. Smith]], who collected the [[type (biology)|type]] specimens from [[Washington (state)|Washington]] in 1941.<ref name="Bas 1969"/> It belongs in the [[subgenus]] ''Lepidella''.

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] has a diameter of 5–17 cm (2–7 in) and is white and scaled with remnants of the [[universal veil]]. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is 6–18 cm (2–7 in) long by {{convert|1|–|3.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, white and similarly scaled, with a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]].<ref name="urlAmanitaceae.org"/> [[Basidiospore|Spore]]s are [[ellipsoid]] to elongated, [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], and measure 11–12.5 by 7–8 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref name="Bas 1969"/>

==Toxicity==
It is responsible for [[mushroom poisoning|poisonings]] in the [[Pacific Northwest]] when mistaken for the [[edible mushroom|edible]] and sought after ''[[Tricholoma murrillianum]]''. It causes initial gastrointestinal symptoms that manifest 1 to 12 hours after eating the mushrooms,<ref name="Greenberg 2005"/> followed by acute [[renal failure]] after a delay of 2–6 days. This is often severe, requiring [[hemodialysis]], but most patients recover normal kidney function within several weeks.<ref name="Saviuc 2006"/> [[Gastroenteritis]] may result in a large loss of [[hypovolemia|fluid volume]]. ''Amanita smithiana'' [[nephrotoxicity]] is from [[chlorocrotylglycine]] and [[allenic norleucine]].<ref name="Greenberg 2005"/>

Several similar species have been implicated in similar cases of acute renal failure: ''[[Amanita sphaerobulbosa|A. sphaerobulbosa]]'', ''[[Amanita thiersii|A. thiersii]]'', ''[[Amanita proxima|A. proxima]]'', (Spain) and ''[[Amanita pseudoporphyria|A. pseudoporphyria]]'' (Japan).<ref name="urlAmanitaceae.org"/>
